review: This device is fantastic for the price. Alas, it's not perfect. Whilst my friend had a simple/flawless installation, I did not (n.b., we both know how to solder and have decades of computer/programming/infrastructure experience).  I had to change my router (despite being "supported").  It's not well-documented that your router must support uPnP traffic (multicast).  Despite having a "supported" router (with uPnP enabled), I had to swap-out the router (I luckily have several laying around).  I contacted tech support... to little effect (they were courteous, fast, and... well, not terribly helpful).  For the money, it's a good deal.  It's mostly reliable (although in the past few weeks I've had to "cold start" (unplug completely) the thing twice to get it to resume responding/functioning properly.  Again, it's a fine product for thirty bucks.

review: I'm a fan of all things cord-cutter-related. I love that innovation is pushing us toward a more mobile and on-demand format for media. That's sweet.Google tried it with Google TV, but it went the way of Google Wave. Cool idea, but implemented poorly.They finally came up with a Roku-esque solution in the Chromecast. And it works (mostly) brilliantly.The selection of Chromecast-compatible apps is a little lacking, but it's a new technology. Give 'em time. The apps that do work, though, are fantastic. YouTube streams extremely well, Netflix works great, and Google's native Play Music store is my most-used function.Here's where it gets dicey, though.Chrome mirroring from a computer is glitchy. It almost seems like an afterthought. Apple's AirPlay is able to perfectly mirror screens and devices with little latency, but for whatever reason, the Chromecast mirroring is slow, buggy, and prone to drop the connection.I realize it's a new tech and first-gen hardware, but it seems like they should have worked out some of the kinks. Oh well.It's still a lot of fun. Google's hardware game is finally stepping up.

When I contacted Google support re: the matter they told me.to buy an app called Plex.  Why should I be forced to purchase a third party app for a product that should work natively with it's creator's other products??? I'm returning it today,  less than 24 hours after purchase.  Disgusted at the waste of time/effort.
